rComments: No homework was turned in. Readings weren't necessary and instead I would look up the texts and read summaries/notes. There were only two types of grades: quizzes and exams. Although that may seem tough, the exams were free-response in blue books and were graded very nicely by TAs. Lecture can get boring tho.

This class was theoretically dense, as expected, but Fain took the time to really unpack all of the texts we read and went over them clearly. He gives thought out responses to questions, and is clearly knowledgeable because his lectures are very interesting. He expects his students to do the readings, but this is college, so what do you expect?

Professor Fain is incredibly knowledgeable and this is super apparent in all of his classes. While the theoretical material is dense, which is to be expected whenever you take a theory course, he is super helpful and really takes the time to help each one of his students for as long as they need. He clearly cares about his students. Recommend!!!

He assigned a lot of dense readings, but you can get an A even if you don't read them. He covers all the test material subtly during lecture. Students who didn't show up to lecture or didn't take notes struggled. The material was difficult to grasp at times, so I would say to only take this class if you have to, or if you really do love philosophy.

This was the hardest GE class I have ever taken. It was taught more as an upper div and quite unfair. His lectures are long and he goes on a lot of tangents. He was not very helpful and unclear about a lot of things. The quizzes and exams were pretty unfair. I would never recommend him.

Lucas is a very smart man, and I found his class to be challenging, but in a great way. He greatly stresses the importance of reading, and I'd recommend it, however, I got an A without ever reading a word. The way I did it was showing up every lecture and  taking close notes. If you pay attention, he'll give all the answers you need.

His lectures are unclear, with a good amount of time spent just reading the textbook aloud with little interpretation. He needs to figure out a way to efficiently take roll. I personally find the topics interesting, but I wouldn't take this class again while Fain is teaching.
He's Fain in the rear end. Enough said.

This class is rather tedious for most people. Lucas is the opposite of approachable and, probably, the most ambiguous lecturer ever. He hardly reveals the format of the quizzes and VERY unclear about the materials. Even if you ask questions, 9 out of 10 times, you won't get a clear response.

Any class with a theoretical subject matter is going to have a lot of reading that is dense, but Professor Fain obviously cared a lot about the themes and texts, and it was extremely rewarding having him guide us in breaking them down. Every class felt like a discussion between us and him, and he took the time to answer any/all questions completely
